Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the research conference "Frontier Probability Days" to be held at Oregon State University, March 29 - 31, 2018. The meeting brings together leading regional and national researchers, graduate students, and other scientists interested in probability theory and its applications, to stimulate research activities in this area and foster new interdisciplinary collaborations. A special feature of the conference is its attention to "applications of probability". Part of the intent of the meeting is to help broaden interaction with other fields, a source of inspiration for both more applied and theoretical aspects of probability research. Much of the support in this award is allocated to travel support for students and early-career researchers, for whom the conference represents an excellent opportunity to stay informed of recent research progress and to initiate research collaborations.

This meeting is the sixth in a series that meets approximately every two years in the Inter-mountain West of the United States. The format consists of ten plenary talks and several shorter presentations. The plenary speakers represent a spectrum of leading work in both theoretical and applied probability. Approximately fifty non-local participants are expected to participate in the conference. Topics of interest include random graphs, stochastic partial differential equations, stochastic networks, and probabilistic applications to biology and dynamical systems. More details can be found at the conference web site:

http://math.oregonstate.edu/~kovchegy/FPD2018/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Frontier Probability Days was a three day conference held from March 29-31, 2018, at Oregon State University in Corvallis, Oregon. Its main purpose was to bring together leading regional and national researchers in probability theory and its applications, especially young researchers and graduate students, to foster interaction and stimulate research activity. In these regards the 2018 edition was an unqualified success.

The conference featured ten plenary speakers who presented research at the forefront of probability theory and its applications. Half of the plenary speakers described theoretical aspects on topics as varied as stochastic partial differential equations, probabilistic aspects of theoretical physics, and intersections between probability and ergodic theory. The other half focused on applications of probability theory to statistical physics, computer science, biology, and earthquake modelling. The focus on applications has become a prominent feature of Frontier Probability Days that distinguishes it from other regional probability conferences. The conference also included shorter talks from an additional 24 researchers, primarily students and beginning scholars. For young participants especially it was an excellent opportunity to highlight their latest research and sharpen their presentation skills. It also allowed young participants an opportunity to expand their network of potential collaborators and mentors, including to members of industry, especially the tech community.  A total of 73 people attended the conference over the three days.

The 2018 conference was the sixth iteration of Frontier Probability Days, with it previously being held in 2007 (Boulder), 2009, 2011, and 2016 (Utah), and 2014 (Arizona). In this short time frame it has become the premier conference for probability research in the Intermountain West. In recent years this region has shown increased vitality in probability theory and its applications, and the focus of this conference series on applications has helped to broaden collaboration with other scientific fields. In turn, this collaboration has become a source of inspiration for more theoretical aspects of probability research.
